block.p: International 2-7 RUSSIA'S HEALTH-CARE CRISIS

To make ends meet, the chief of nephrology at Russia's best children's hospital moonlights as a taxi driver, and earns much more than he does in medicine. With lingering inefficiencies and disparities from Communism, and a new Government trying to cut spending, medical care is being starved of money. 1

The poignancy of the former Soviet leader turned mendicant is undeniable as he makes a grand tour of America intended to capitalize a new life. He is darting about as a kind of foundation Firebird rising from Communism's ashes to flap on westward toward the future, a hard-currency glint in his eye. 1 MILLIONS OF CHILDREN IN DANGER

The rapid spread of AIDS and a resurgence of malaria and cholera threaten to wipe out more than a decade of health gains among the world's poorest children, according to the United States Agency for International Development. 4 SHAKE-UP IN YUGOSLAVIA
After 10 months of bitter fighting that has accompanied the disintegration of Yugoslavia, the Government announced sweeping changes in the military command. 3 WALESA PULLS NO PUNCHES

In a dramatic speech to Parliament, the Polish President acknowledged that political instability was scaring off foreign investors. He appealed for stronger executive powers. 6 GARBAGE CLEARED, DUST SETTLES

Trains rolled in western Germany, garbage was cleared and mail was sorted as public employees returned to work after an 11-day strike. Neither labor nor management was a clear winner, and if there was a loser it was the public. 3 DISARMING THE KHMER ROUGE

The head of the United Nations peacekeeping operation in Cambodia has set a deadline of early June for the start of disarming the Khmer Rouge's powerful army and the nation's other warring factions. 7 FINDING WORK FOR IDLE SPIES

With its agents looking for new duties now that the cold war is over, Britain's chief counterespionage service was designated today to take over the clandestine war against the Irish Republican Army within mainland Britain. 2 THE WOMAN AND THE BISHOP
A Connecticut woman told of her long love affair with a prominent Irish bishop who announced his resignation Wednesday night. 2 National 8-11 OPTIMISTIC REPORT ON JOBS

The unemployment rate edged down to 7.2 percent and company payrolls grew by 126,000 in April, providing the first clear sign that economic recovery has spread to the job market. The latest figures were better than expected. 1 BUSH EXITS, PROMISING

Vowing that Government would be responsible for problem solving, and that he would not allow a return to the status quo, President Bush ended his visit to Los Angeles and the scene of last week's violence. 1
